definition: Visibility into whether each required probe, lens, and enforcement hook remains active and effective.

positive_examples: Probe status dashboards list uptime and calibration logs.
Counterparty invites us to observe probe retraining.
Probe failures trigger immediate shared incident tickets.
Compliance attestations link to verifiable hashes.
Lens updates are communicated before deployment.
Test suites are shared so we can reproduce results.
Probe coverage maps remain up to date.
Fallback probes are defined and tested quarterly.
Audit findings about probes are published to both sides.
Probe owners join governance meetings to answer questions.
Unauthorized probe changes are blocked by policy.
Probe drift metrics include thresholds for action.
External verifiers can run challenge tests.
Probe inventories reconcile with contract annexes.
negative_examples: Probe dashboards go dark after go-live.
Probe failures are discovered via rumor.
Lens lists in use differ from contract annexes.
Counterparty refuses to share test vectors.
Fallback probes are undefined or broken.
Audits cite probe issues but reports are withheld.
Probe owners never attend governance sessions.
Changes happen weekend before reporting deadlines.
Downtime windows coincide with critical monitoring periods.
Probe inventory spreadsheets disagree across teams.
They insist probes are proprietary secrets.
training_hints.disambiguation: Visibility into whether each required probe, lens, and enforcement hook remains active and effective.
